And you thought your kid had long hair!  Definitely a period-piece, you'll be sure to enjoy.I'll keep this short.  Go buy it. reviewText: Yes, "Rush in Rio" has a great, enthusiastic crowd because A.) it's in an open-air stadium and B.) Rush had never played Rio before, so you had people waiting 30 years to see their favorite band (or one of their favorite bands) in concert for the very first time. But that is not enough reason to knock "R30." First off, the German crowd on "R30" isn't as sedate as some reviewers below claim. They have their hands in the air, dancing, playing air drums in honor of Neil Peart, clapping and stomping to the music. Just look and see the sea of arms and hands in the air during many of the shots. I get tickled when people have the misconeption that a crowd who isn't crowd-surfing, foaming at the mouth, throwing bear on each other and fist-fighting "is a bad, lame crowd." Whatever. Maybe many of those German fans ARE Rush fanatics, and maybe they are musicians themselves who want to .... (drum roll) .... WATCH and HEAR the trio perform, and not act like an idiot at a Grateful Dead or Jimmy Buffett concert. A Rush concert isn't an "EVENT" like the Dead, where it's "Look at me, I'm at a concert and I'm cool and tough and yada yada yada." With Rush, it's the music and the musicianship. The gripes about the German crowd on this DVD are completely unwarranted. And to top it off, the crowd is loud, it's just that the audience isn't recorded as loudly as the Brazilian crowd on "Rush In Rio." Good grief, aren't you people happy to have a great live version of "Red Barchetta" on DVD, while all of us wait for the new "Exit Stage Left" DVD to be released sometime in 2006? The negative reviews below really are nitpicking. "R30" has great editing (so three or four songs are missing from the set, big deal), great camera work and great sound. And Rush's playing, as always, is without peers. Pick up the deluxe edtion which has the audio CDs, a guitar pick each from Alex and Geddy, and a mock backstage pass. Enjoy!
summary: Rush R30 is a great DVD, contrary to what some are saying

reviewText: Being 22, it's hard to imagine that Rush has been around for 30 years. They've had a quite long varied career that manages to keep fans from 30 years ago or make new ones. The last DVD in Rio was quite good although some of my favorite songs weren't included and with a band like Rush there's always something they missed. This setlist I think is actually shorter than the last one but that's ok, they play enough "vault" hits that you forgive them.Opening with the R30 overture, it's a medly of previous songs such as Finding My Way, Cygnus X-1, Hemispheres and some other forgotten gems. Now it's nice to have Hemispheres finally on a recent DVD but since it's about 2 minutes of an 18 minute song it's kinda disappointing. Then it goes into Spirit of Radio which always so fun. 2 of my favorites come in a row as Animate and Subdivisions come.From there we have songs that they played last time in Rio or brand new ones from the Feedback EP. Also they have Between the Wheels which I think hasn't even been played ever. While it's a nice song I would've preferred something else from Grace Under Pressure such as Red Sector A or Distant Early Warning. One surprising entry is Heart Full of Soul where Rush unplug and go acoustic and it's quite a lively track. Then we get 2112, Xanadu and Working Man(not the entire tracks for them) and they close with Limelight.Disc 2 has Rush rarities, such as some songs in the studio, performed live and their induction into the Canadian hall of fame. The next 2 discs are just the concert on CD similar to Rio except it's packaged in one set rather than separately. One thing that was nice was autographed pics by Alex Lifeson and Geddy Lee as well as a backstage pass.One disappointment as you can obviously figure out with a DVD release: omitted songs. My favorite Rush track(and probably in my top 3 songs ever) Bravado isn't even on here as well as any instrumental. There's one song from Vapor Trails(I prefer One Little Victory personally, instead it's Earthshine) and I don't even think Presto got a mention. But every DVD has this but still, since it's several songs short you'd think they'd include maybe 2 more.Celebrating a band's anniversary is always an event so you got to have something to show for it and R30 is a nice entry even if you don't get everything from those 30 years you want.
summary: Wow 30 years and they can still rock

reviewText: The GoodThe special edition of the DVD set is so full of material that you can hardly dislodge it from its box. I've never really been a fan of Rush, but this collection packs one hell of a bang for the buck. Disc 1 features a concert that was filmed in Germany last year during Rush's World tour. The two hour show is prefaced by a trippy animation sequence that features scenes from all of their album covers. I still don't understand was Jerry Stiller kicks off the show, but that's beside the point. Rush take the stage to get the ball rolling with a medley of instrumentals simple titled "R30 Overture."From their it's on the 19 songs of hits and favorites that include; "The Spirit of Radio," "Subdivisions," "Roll the Bones," "Tom Sawyer", "Summertime Blues," and "Limelight." I've always heard how great and eccentric a drummer Neil Peart was, but it wasn't until this DVD that I really got to experience it. "Der Trommler" is where he really shines. I can't believe he can remember what drum head does what on his drum kit. I've never seen such a complicated set up. It doesn't matter though; Peart clearly knows what he's doing. I thought it went on a little long, but that's just me. The show sounds spectacular in 5.1 sound as well as stereo, and the band gives a top-notch, flawless performance.That's not all folks. Disc 2 features five interviews with the band that span 23 years; 1979, 1981, 1990, 1994, and 2002. I could care less about these interviews, but I'm sure fans will eat them up, at least for one viewing. It was kind of cool to hear how their plans change or what they were thinking during a particular time frame. In addition to the interviews you get what is dubbed as "The Anthem Vault". This is more or less a collection of videos, commercial, live, or bootleg, of the band's hits that, for the most part, weren't preformed on disc one. There's a couple that appeared on the first disc.Is that enough for you? I hope not, because there's more. The packaging stated there are `easter eggs', but as the band says, `good luck finding them.' There's a commemorative booklet with lots of band photos and even a backstage pass tucked inside. If you want to take the show with you in the car, included in the set are two audio CDs of the Germany concert. And finally, to make it even more special, you get two guitar picks, one from Alex Lifeson and one from Geddy Lee. I'm sure they would have thrown in a drum stick if they could.The BadNothingThe VerdictYou shouldn't even bother calling yourself a Rush fan if you don't have this DVD collection. Even as a non-Rush fan I found this collection to be simply awesome. Now someone please explain to me the significance of the washer & dryer on stage.
summary: Even as a non-Rush fan I found this collection to be simply awesome

reviewText: Some great footage of early Rush from Fly by Night, Farewell to Kings - but I'm pretty sure it's dubbed, though the dubbing is high quality, i.e. you might not know it's dubbed unless you knew the original album material well. It's great to see shots of these 3 players from different intervals in their career.  "Freewill", while in the vault, is not actually ancient footage - 2003 - washing machines in background!  It's cool to see, but i'd have loved to more good footage (if any exists) from earlier 'man-in-the-star' days.One of the real gems from the vaults is some seriously old footage (with quality to match) of 'finding my way' - no dubbing here - this is early Rush in all their raw glory.  The quality is a notch up from a garage recording, but I'd rather it this way to see the real thing anyday over a quality dub.  This is vintage Rush, although i'm pretty sure Neil and not Rutsy is on the drums here.  Alex's got his Jimmy Page steps down, and Geddy's belting it out like a punk rocker - looking pretty mean!  Another treat is La Villa Strangiato from Hemispheres days which is also not a dub, while picture and sound quality are pretty good. reviewText: I suspect many/most people who buy this will have been to the R30 concert at some venue, somewhere. I was there, and I desperately wanted a memento of that superb event in Manchester, UK.R30 is "sort of" it, but the poor crowd response and the significant cuts from the set list ( including Alex' brilliant rap / rant ) made this a little like looking at a print of the Mona Lisa .... there is a similarity and you get a sense of what the original is like, but there is a feeling that there is something very fundamental missing and it leaves you a little empty. You still NEED to see the original. R30 is "sort of like I remember" but what about that particular song, and that fantastic guitar solo?. R30 is NOT how I remember it.It is a photo cropped, airbrushed, and auto adjusted until it is just no longer how you remember itThe sound quality and visuals are superb but compared to Rush in Rio it is NOT the event. RiR was a moment in time, captured with all its flaws, but was a complete picture of a mesmerising performance by the "lads", spurred on by an adrenalin pumped audience of brilliant fans. Good or bad, at least it it was the complete story.On the other hand, R30 is NOT the event. It is part of it, and it feels a little hollow because of that.If you can overcome that feeling of "Why the HELL is it not all there !" or you did not get to see the concerts, then you will be OK. It is a great DVD. If you can overcome the feeling of "will DVD producers EVER get it right !!" you will be delighted with what is a visual feast, and a musical treat ( even if you have heard it probably a million times already )The extras on disc 2 were great, I must admit most of it was new to me, and the interviews were informative. OK, if you are a TRUE Rush fan, I am sure you have libraries of this stuff, so I suppose I am not really a true fan :-). However, I did think some of the quality of the recordings of the early band perfomances was pretty pathetic, and the sound check was a waste of time and effort. Why could they have not shown the sound check from this concert, as at least it would have been relevant and interesting to hear them comment on the merits or otherwise of this venue.gripe gripe gripe. I know. R30 is still a fantastic thing. In terms of band musicianship / recording quality it is the Statue of David compared to most of the crud out there, but I am left with the feeling that it would have been SO much better the way it was meant to be, COMPLETE with both arms ... hands. Ah, a show of hands .... I knew I was getting literary in my old age.

reviewText: Of all the major bands of my teens, only Rush and U2 have never done a "comeback" or a "reunion."  This, of course, is because they've never been gone.There is something almost eerie about that.  Twenty years ago, my friends and I were playing furious air guitar with pool sticks in my parents' basement, while a vinyl copy of "2112" did its best to exceed the limits of a hand-me-down stereo.Today, I'm a husband and father, working very hard to keep the gut away.  Yet somehow, Alex, Geddy and Neil are still here, just like they always were - and like me they've gotten older and (except for Geddy) a bit wider around the middle.  Which makes it even cooler that they still ABSOLUTELY ROCK!During the Overture on this R30 DVD, they seamlessly present themes from 2112, Fly By Night, Rush, Hemispheres and more.  If you close your eyes, and just listen, you expect to open them and see young, skinny, long-haired Rush straining vintage 1970's equipment in some kind of Rock and Roll time warp.  You expect to suddenly hear Geddy go high and start singing those searing notes that he used to hit.When you open your eyes, you see older, wider, short-haired (except for Geddy) Rush straining modern equipment, changed physically by time but obviously still the exact same band that inspired me, for example, to take my speakers off my wall in college and lay down between them so that I could catch every last nuance of the entire "Farewell to Kings" album on one of the first CD's I ever bought.As the years went by, I moved on to other bands, and my complete Rush CD collection began to scatter into the piles with the hundreds of others.  I thought that I had moved on.In watching this concert with the headphones cranked up, I got that same sense of awe and excitement I had in college.  I found myself sitting upright, not just listening but mentally cheering for my onetime heroes, who were suddenly heroes all over again.I haven't seen the "Rio" DVD, but in R30 Rush will remind every true fan of why we're all so happy that they have never gone away.  I have a huge DVD music collection, and some of it is buried way in the back.  R30 is one to keep on the front row.

reviewText: You know, I am a fairly conservative guy and as such generally do not spend much time complaining about products or indulging in conspiracy theories and generally griping about stuff. But I am also a big music nut and as a fan I expect something back from the rock bands who I have helped make rich and famous over long careers. See, I am the type of fan that, given a band that I really enjoy... I will buy EVERYTHING. So for literally hundreds of bands, from Aerosmith to Zappa and most in between, I have gone a long way in lining their pockets.Therefore I think I have a right to speak out when I am shortchanged. Rush have severely disappointed me. If the band members are not the planners of this little sales strategy, they are certainly second hand guilty parties by not putting their hands up and saying "no way will we allow this!" And for those of you who will leap up and give a knee-jerk defense to the band I say you need to stop and think first. How on earth can the record label, the management or the band defend releasing a Bluray with none of the extras that were present on the DVD version? Especially when it is being released on a format that could have included hours of additional extras!?Rush have been somewhat generous in releasing archival material, but not as generous as they could be. Looking at the awesome live clip they gave us of La Villa Strangiato from '79, I have to wonder "why not give the fans the whole damn show?" Because you're embarassed about a flowery shirt or some flubbed notes? Come on guys... couldn't you be a bit more generous? I understand the artists' impulse to want only perfect performances to represent their legacy... but all their fan's have been to the concerts and heard the mistakes, and still pay for the tickets and buy the records (usually too many times), always forgiving the mis-steps and loving the concerts anyway.Point is, I am really sick of artists wanting to hold back on vault material, just giving fans little teases here and there and leaving them wishing for more from the band that they handed out their hard-earned money to over the course of many years or, as in this case, many decades, making them rich and famous along the way. Of the two sides to this argument I think the loyal fans that gave these musicians a career deserve to win the argument more often than not, but generally they loose.The R30 bluray is a perfect example of the fans loosing BIG TIME. I waited patiently for a Bluray realease of this set, knowing that the techno-saavy boys in Rush would want to send this out in high def. Now I knew before buying it online that the extras were not listed on the back. I had checked it out in the store. But I foolishly thought "no, they wouldn't possibly leave the extras out, in fact, there are probably more than on the DVD." I couldn't believe it when I put the Bluray in... just couldn't believe it. A few extra songs to finish the concert is nice, but where are all the extras... were are the extended interviews? Where is the making of the concert video documentary? Where is the extra hour of archive videos in addition to those already on the DVD. And even if you wouldn't add all that, where is the stuff that was already there!!I'm sorry, but there's no excuse for this. Instead of getting the nice package that I was waiting for, I was forced yet again to buy the same thing twice. Lucky for me the DVD is still available, but I shouldn't have to buy the same thing twice, Geddy, Neil and Alex! I have everything you have released and I already bought your CDs twice... ALL the remasters. And here I am buying twice something that was only recently released. Of course, shame on me for expecting better from the band I love and their management.My advice to the fans out there that haven't purchased already... The difference between the DVD and Bluray on my High Def system with large LED widescreen: minimal. Actually the DVD looks absolutely awesome, and it's only if you perform an A-B test that you can see the minor differences. If you get the DVD you will have all the extras along with a great sounding and looking modern concert. The few additional concert tracks on the bluray are non-essential for me, with every previous live video already in my collection. This Bluray was one of the biggest let-downs I have experienced in a long, long time.If the record label and management wanted to make sure they sold through all the copies of the DVD they should have held off on releasing the Bluray instead of forcing fans into an extra purchase.Now I've said my piece... I would encourage others that agree to let the band know what you think.
summary: An Angry and Cheated fan speaks!

reviewText: The R30 tour DVD is a must-buy for Rush fans, although from the other reviews here on Amazon it's interesting to see that with this release the band, once again, have polarized their fan base. Many fans seem to take it all very personally - too personally in my opinion - so with that in mind, here are my two cents:Rush: On top form. Play with enthusiasm and vigor. Alex in particular has a good night. The Frankfurt crowd definitely get their money's worth.The DVD: Picture and sound are top notch. Good editing, and the cuts between shots are not too fast. Call me old fashioned, but I always choose the stereo option on DVD's, and on this release it sounds superb.Set list: Now to the meat of the debate...The omission of eight songs from the tour setlist is disappointing. "The Trees" is a personal fave, and "One Little Victory" was, for me, a highlight of the show. More importantly, in the digital age there is just no excuse for shortening a performance, as used to happen all the time with vinyl and VHS. Inclusion of the "Feedback" tracks is a personal thing. I like the version of "The Seeker", could do without the others, but wonder overall if the whole idea really worked. Plenty of quality Rush material got sacrificed to make time for the cover versions. Also, and I guess this will be seen as sacrilegious by some, I could really do without the 10-minute drum solo. I am a drummer. Neil Peart is a big influence. But his solos just don't do it for me. Play a couple more songs with the band...Crowd: Many reviewers seem to bemoan the fact that the German crowd are not "into it" enough. Well, from my experience at the R30 show in Hartford, Conn., that is a good thing. If drunken Americans screaming out every lyric to every song, constantly getting up to buy more beer, puking, and scuffling makes for a great show, then count me out. I think the German fans do just fine.Extras: I am not much of a Rush completist, so the extras - mostly interviews and old videos - are of some interest, but not essential. On the other hand, when it comes to Rush nostalgia, the DVD release of Exit...Stage Left, reportedly due in '06, will do me just fine.Overall: For a band that has been together for 30 years, Rush are in remarkably good shape. Always enigmatic, and always independent, their music does their talking. The exclusion of eight songs from the show does seem like a major, and baffling, lack of judgement, but I doubt it will affect the commercial prospects of this DVD. All Rush fans, whatever their age and favorite band period, will find something to enjoy on this release.

reviewText: THE SET: (2005) There are two versions of this "R30" DVD release. The 2-disc version (DVD's only), and the deluxe 4-disc version (2 DVD's and 2 CD's). For some reason, as of December 2006, the 2-disc set is more expensive than the 4-disc set here on Amazon. Disc-1 gives you the 130 minute concert from Frankfurt, Germany (Sept 2004) filmed in 5.1 Surround. Disc-2 gives you five interviews and 10 videos (some live, some staged) from the archives. Disc-3 and Disc-4 are CD's of the same Frankfurt concert from Disc-1... both music discs run just over 61 minutes. The deluxe set comes with 2 guitar picks (with Lee's and Lifeson's stamped autograph); and a nice 22-page booklet containing numerous band photos over the last 3 decades, DVD written contents, and a list of those that labored with the band (tour crews, editors, mgmt, etc). Label - Anthem.COMMENTS: This is a must own for any Rush fan. As of this release, Rush has 28 studio/live/compilation releases... a massive career beginning with their 1974 debut. Simply a ton of great music. Disc-1 opens with a very cool 2-minute animated intro - incorporating all the artwork from each of their albums; followed by a short intro (not sure what else to call it) from comedian Jerry Stiller. Rush's Frankfurt concert itself is shot beautifully and the camera speed it moves from shot to shot is not too fast (as many music DVD's are). The track list is great - though with such a large catalog of songs to choose from, there was going to be some glaring omissions of some classic songs (i.e. - "Fly By Night", "Freewill", "New World Man", "One Little Victory", "The Trees", "Closer To The Heart", "Distant Early Warning", etc). The band sounds absolutely awesome. As much as Lifeson's guitar solos are highlights, Peart's drum solo ("Der Trommler") is mesmerizing. Geddy Lee's bass is a constant, and his voice can still hit the high notes (well, most of the time). The interviews on disc-2 (about 55 minutes in total) are a nice insight to the band. From Geddy Lee's interview in 1979 outside Ivor Wynne Stadium (in Hamilton) through their 2002 Vapor Trails band interview... discussing a wide range of topics - from their albums, concepts/ideas, successes, failures & hard times, image, touring, audience reactions, influences, unique sound, anger, memories, balance and staying power. My favorite of these interviews was the Juno Hall Of Fame induction - with many famous faces contributing (Tom Cochran, Mike Myers, Sebastian Bach, Tragically Hip, Kim Mitchell, Primus, Soundgarden, Joe Carter & Paul Molitor from the Toronto Blue Jays, and more). The videos on disc-2 were neat for the nostalgia buffs - great songs being played (or lip-synced), complete with corny sets, dated clothes, bad haircuts/perms, terrible sound and a much smaller drum kit for Neil Peart. The highlights are probably "A Farewell To Kings" and the more recent in-studio "Closer To The Heart". The compact discs are a bonus to listen to on the home stereo or cranked in the car. A truly awesome package all the way around (5 stars).

reviewText: "R30" is a simply brilliant live achievement for famed Canadian rockers Rush. My Rush fandom was remarkably revitalized recently after seeing them on their latest tour, and for me "R30" is the next best thing to being there. Of course the prime attraction is the concert DVD (Disc One,) but the extras in the package are equal to the performance recorded at the Festhalle in Frankfurt, Germany. There's a great DVD of extras including rare performances and interviews, a beautifully produced booklet, two souvenir guitar picks, and a two CD set of the concert, which is now near the top of my personal play list, and which is only available with this set.The performances are great and spot on. I was particularly glad to see them pay homage to some of their influences with outstanding performances of "Crossroads," "Summertime Blues," and "The Seeker." Of course I love the originals, but I actually think I like these high-voltage cover versions even better. All the Rush mega-hits are here too, with "Limelight" and "Working Man" being among the best versions out there (I am especially fond of the reggae refrain in "Working Man" heard here, although I liked it even better on the latest tour with the reggae opening instead.)The video quality is excellent, and the audio sounds great. Geddy's vocals are in good shape, Neil's drum work is indescribably good ("Der Trommler" is an amazing technical performance for drum enthusiasts,) and the solo work from Alex is even better than normal if that's even remotely comprehensible. Rush has fun with their shows and don't take themselves too seriously, and here the best manifestations of that are the cameos of Jerry Stiller that open and close the live show complaining about how they never play "A Passage to Bangkok:" he is richly rewarded for his kvetching to great comedic effect.I am thrilled with R30, and I recommend it highly to Rush fans or fans of live music anywhere.

reviewText: Rush: R30 special edition - I listened to a lot of Rush between the ages of 12 and 17. In real time terms, that meant the "Moving Pictures," "Signals," "Grace Under Pressure," and "Power Windows" albums. Of course, I also listened to the local classic rock station, which meant that I heard all of the albums before that as well, including Side A of "2112' many many many times. And since those days I can count the number of Rush fans I have met on one hand. Having gone many years without paying them much attention, I was happy to see that they'd put out this cool set: it's a live CD and a live DVD of their 30th anniversary tour. There is also an additional DVD that shows a lot of archival footage, which means you get to see Rush haircuts and stage gear throughout the decades; the set also comes with two guitar picks, one signed by Geddy Lee and one signed by Alex Lifeson. I use these picks to play guitar. Rock and roll!!! The live DVD was filmed in Frankfurt in 2003. It starts out with a weird animated sequence that is full of either three-part objects or motifs from their album covers - the dalmation from Signals appears both solo and in a herd of charging dalmations (?!?). Those Rush guys sure have a wacky sense of humour. Some of the parts were quite Monty Python Terry Gilliam-esque, which is nice, especially the segueway from the Starman "whoa, sorry dude" to the man with the bowler hat from the Hemispheres album cover. Albums covers include Caress of Steel man, Power Windows kid, Fly By Night owl, Presto rabbits, Signals dalmation becomes dalmation herd, Counterparts nut and bolt, toys thingy, farewell to Kings mannequin, Moving Pictures' moving pictures, starman jumps out of painting to enter Hemispheres cover. Then three dinosaurs hatching from eggs saying "hello, Hel-lo, HELLO." Then the Jerry Stiller intro on the screen where he talks about Lars, Dirk, the Professor. "I hope they play Bangkok... nahhhhh, they never play Bangkok." Funny stuff. Then out pops the band for a medley of their really old old old songs from their first six albums: "Finding my Way," the first song from the first album, "Anthem," the first song from the second albume, "Bastille Day," the first song from the third album, "A Passage to Bangkok," the first song from the second side of the fourth album, "Cygnus X-1' the last song on the fifth album, and then "Hemispheres," (also known as "Cygnus X-1 Book 2') which is the first song on the sixth album. A lot of symmetry there. The whole time they showed pictures of the musicians as young men, and Jerry Stiller rocking out to "A Passage to Bangkok." That is followed by "The Spirit of Radio," and the first time you hear Geddy Lee singing. The three guys look great for fifty-year-olds! Strangely, Geddy Lee now finally looks his age, as he looked fifty-something even as a thirty-something; Alex Lifeson is a bit heavy and balding, although he finally has a haircut that doesn't look awful. From some shots you can notice that he's got a big bald patch at the back of his head. Neil Peart is a bit heavy, and a terminator behind his kit pounding out any complex rhythm with machine-like precision. It's just amazing to behold, although a little creepy too - he almost never shows any emotion at all. He has a cool kit adorned with stickers from different album covers - these guys are serious about their iconography!! Meanwhile, Neil and Geddy look like they're having the time of their lives - Geddy is wiry and animated, bouncing his right leg with the beat, Alex has that slack-jawed mindfulness of what he's playing, just an amazing musician. Geddy plays a Fender Jazz bass most of the concert, Alex plays several Paul Reed Smith guitars, a red Gibson SG, a gold Gibson Les Paul, and for Xanadu a white double-headed Gibson SG that has a six-string and a 12-string guitar in it. Cool stuff!!! Alex's side of the stage is full of amps, Geddy's has... laundry dryers spinning. They spin and they spin and they spin. There's also some sort of a vending machine up there. The concert goes on with plenty of mid-career classics like "Force Ten" and "Subdivisions." Also some new songs that I've grown to enjoy like "Animate" and "Earthshine." During "Red Barchetta" There's a great top-down shot of Neil throwing his drumstick up in the air and catching it, then you see him head-on turn the stick 180 degrees and carry on playing (39:20). They must have planned that drumstick toss shot and installed a special camera just to pick it up. I wonder if there's not a bit of post-production work there. Still, it's a great moment. "Roll The Bones" is a cool song, with some groovy animated skeleton (think Jason and the Argonauts) rapping along with Geddy. "The Seeker," a cover of the Who song is good fun. Then they go into "Darn That Dragon," a weird animated bit that shows angel rabbits, dragons selecting TV shows, popping their own fire-breath popcorn, then a great show of an animated bobblehead Rush "featuring Dirrk, Lerxst, and Pratt" (i.e. Geddy, Alex and Neil). There's a star alert, a dragon is attacking the city, Rush intercept in their Cygnus X-2 Rockership, the dragon tries to burn down the asbestos factory, bobble heads sweat, he burns down the Rush Merchandise stall. This means war!!! They fire "the ultimate weapon," the dragon trips over the metro and falls onto the high tension wires. Bobble heads bobbing in tune with the music, which changes with every scene to another high-powered Rush early classic. Great great stuff that phases into "Tom Sawyer." Cool. Alex singing along on "Between The Wheels," which they dug out of the vaults, chest hair popping out of shirt (1:10:00). Slack-jawed while soloing, then thumping body to keep the vibrato going. Mystic Rhythms very cool to watch - there's so much going on between Neil's two hands and two feet. This, of course, leads in to the 9-minute drum solo that is really soooooo boring to listen to on the CD, but quite captivating to watch on the DVD. For example, there is one part where he's tapping out on the drums, and then reaches up to tap an electric xylophone pad. He repeats the same pattern several times, always managing to hit that same little pad again and again, playing with his head turned the other direction, meaning that he's playing blind!!! I'm not a fan of drum solos, but this one was quite amazing to watch and study. The highlight was when the drum kit rotated 180 degrees (while Neil stayed still), to show a big bass drum with the starman logo on it. Cool. After that there's a bit of an acoustic set - "Resist" and the Yardbirds classic "Heart Full of Soul" - before the big moment of the concert: 2112!!! The intro seems like it was recorded, as the stage was cast in darkness, then when the guitars come in - light! Here the band's eccentric sense of humour gets the better of them and for a brief moment there are pirates onstage swashbuckling. Who swashbuckles any more these days? Geddy also has a stuffed parrot on his shoulder, which just looks out of place. But it's a great song, and Alex is playing a gorgeous black Les Paul... The band plays two more covers during their encore, "Summertime Blues" (a la the Blue Cheer version) and "Crossroads," as well as the very appropriate "Limelight." Lovely. DVD 2 is divided between interviews through the ages, and classic live recordings. There's a 1979 one with Geddy only that is tres serious. He's talking about how the band recorded "Hemispheres," and is mentioning "Permanent Waves," which is a "non-concept" album, a first for the band, that they were getting ready to go into the studio for at the time, but wasn't fully formed yet. It's a windy day and his hair is blowing all over his face, but I got to learn that the band is really into Yes, and especially their drummer, Bill Bruford. The next one is in 1981 and is with all three. Neil Peart is really serious but still a good sport, Geddy is wearing super ugly glasses and smoking cigarettes (?!?), while Alex nearly doesn't speak at all and seems really awkward. One "funny" point that was made was how during the recording of "Caress of Steel" recording sessions they took a night off and went to see Yes play, and after that they didn't want to finish the album (it ended up being one of their worst-selling records). There were interesting "Artist of the Decade" interviews, that shows Alex finally speaking up more, and also a Juno awards Hall of Fame induction that has a serious Tom Cochrane talking about the band, with video messages from Mike Myers and Sebastian Bach and The Barenaked Ladies. Then there is the "Vapour Trails" interview from 2002 with Alex and Geddy that was done after the band had come back together following Neil Peart's dual tragedy (his daughter was killed in a car wreck in 1997, his wife died of grief a year later) to record and tour again. An interesting point of Geddy's is that on this album he was playing his bass more guitar-like while Alex was playing his guitar more bass-like. The interview sets are followed by great archival footage. "Fly By Night" looks like it was recorded on the set of Hilarious House of Frightenstein. "Finding My Way" is very Led Zeppelin. "In the Mood" is very Led Zeppelin and very embarassing (lyrically). "La Villa Strangiato" is fantastic virtuoso musicianship, much like 2112 or Xanadu. "A Farewell To Kings" is set in a forest and a castle before switching to a "stage" environment. Geddy Lee is wearing this awful bathrobe over his regular clothes, very yucky. The clothes of that era were terrible, making you appreciate how these good these old guys look wearing jeans onstage. There are more recent live shows, such as Toronto Rocks in 2003, and even a soundcheck. Hey, why not throw in everything? The fans will sure be happy.

reviewText: Rush's most recent live album/DVD R30, which was released in November of 2005, is a must for all Rush fans.Recorded and filmed during the band's 30th anniversary tour in Frankfurt, Germany in September of 2004, I saw the band outside Boston, MA a month before this concert was filmed (was my fourth time I had seen Rush, have seen them every tour since Counterparts) and this DVD brings me back to that night. What great showmen/performers the three wise men of Rush are!Bass player/singer/keyboard player Geddy Lee, guitarist Alex Lifeson and drummer Neil Peart get better with age I tell you.The first DVD/CD starts with an opening animated movie which had all of their album covers come alive and Jerry Stiller (father of actor Ben) asking where Rush is and BANG we begin with "The R30 OVERTURE" (which consisted of teasers of Finding My Way, Anthem, Bastille Day, A Passage to Bangkok, Cygnus X-1 and Hemispheres) and just rocked, what a way to kick off an awesome CD/DVD. Next is a spirited "The Spirit of Radio". Next is possibly the best version of "Force Ten". Next is a slightly shorter "Animate" which is a great version. "Subdivisions" is next and a great live reading which is better than the Show of Hands version by a LONGSHOT. "Earthshine" is next and is a great number. Next is "Red Barchetta" and rivals the version on Exit...Stage Left. Next is "Roll the Bones" and just rocks. Missing I know from first set is Bravado, YYZ and The Trees (they are on Rush in Rio DVD) but c'est la vie! Next is a stellar cover of The Who classic "The Seeker". The first set closer One Little Victory (with dragon film/pyro) is missing but you can't have them all. Next is the dragon TV surfing before settling on the full Darn That Dragon film (I always laugh watching this) and we go into "Tom Sawyer" which kicked off the second half of the show. "Dreamline" is next and is a great version (and ends the first CD). Secret Touch would have followed but is absent but you can't have it all.We then have a stellar version of the deep track "Between the Wheels" (which kicks off CD #2) and is a great song. Next is the song "Mystic Rhythms" which is a great version and decimated the Show of Hands version. The next song in show Red Sector A is missing but it's on Rush in Rio which brings us to "Der Trommler" which is Neil's eight and a half minute drum solo which shows he is one drummer who gets better with age (he is still the drum GOD today!!!). Next is an unplugged "Resist" which is very good. Following that is "Heart Full of Soul" which is a great version of The Yardbirds classic. Next is 1/2 of "2112" consisting of Overture/Temples of Syrinx (Geddy changes the end line to We Are the Pirates sung in pirate voice)/Grand Finale and killer. La Villa Strangiato (with humorous Alex rant) and By-Tor and the Snow Dog are missing but Rush didn't want to have repeats though some complain that they do. We then go into "Xanadu" which is a good six minute reading of the Farewell to Kings classic cut. "Working Man" follows and is a great version and I like the reggae bit before the song ends. "Summertime Blues" is next and rocks followed by a spirited "Crossroads" and ending with a killer "Limelight" (and ending Jerry Stiller movie).The Second DVD consists of rare promos and performances which are the Church Session video for Fly by Night from 1975, 2 mpegs videos of In The Mood and Finding My Way from Don Kirshner's Rock Concert in 1974, live in the studio performances of Circumstances and La Villa Strangiato, the 1977 promo fims of A Farewell to Kings and Xanadu, a sound check version of The Spirit of Radio from Ivor Wynne Stadium in 1979, Freewill from the Toronto SARS benefit in 2003 and lastly Closer to the Heart (with one of The Barenaked Ladies and Bubbles from The trailer Park Boys) from the Canadian Tsunami Relief show in 2005. Also, many interviews from 1979, 1980, 1990 and 2002 plus Rush's 1994 induction into the Canadian Music Hall of Fame (in full with soundbytes from Chris Cornell, Mike Myers, Sebastian Bach and many others).Also on deluxe edition, you get a 16-page booklet plus two Rush guitar picks and a backstage pass from the R30 show [R30 : sticker].Don't get the 2-DVD, go for the DELUXE EDITION! This was the best release of 2005!
summary: The older that Rush get the better they get
